docs.lead_paragraph: LIKE thousands of high school seniors across New Jersey, Jason Kenney is looking forward to graduation -- and the partying afterward. But where once the traditional party meant an all-night drunken bash at the shore, the post-graduation activities here June 25 will be substance free and -- organizers contend -- more fun.

docs.lead_paragraph: ''MY name is Jay, and I'm an alcoholic in recovery,'' said the young man, introducing himself. He listed low points in his life: smoking marijuana at 13, drinking alcohol at 14, dropping out of high school, drinking before work, getting fired from job after job, being arrested for armed robbery and attempting to hang himself in jail. A prison guard cut him down in time, Jay M. got counseling and began attending Alcoholics Anonymous meetings. ''Today, I take care of my kids and I do the responsible thing,'' he said. ''I don't have alcohol in my house.'' After applauding Jay's progress, members of the group talked about their own successes and failures at staying sober. It could have been any A.A. meeting except that it was held at East Hartford High School. In 1993, the school established a student assistance center offering alcohol and drug counseling, support groups, weekly A.A. meetings and treatment referrals as well as career planning, peer mediation and conflict resolution. Recently, the school was recognized by the Federal Department of Education for its success in helping troubled students.

headline.main: Adding A.A. to The 3 R's At School

docs.lead_paragraph: What's in a name? Increasingly for makers of generic drugs, everything -- a seemingly odd state of affairs for an industry whose stock in trade is cheap no-name knockoffs of brands that have lost their patents. With too many players in too many parts of the business, companies that primarily sell generics often find themselves lost in the crowd, able to stand out on pharmacy shelves only by cutting prices. More and more, though, they are replacing the identically drab scientific labels on their products with brand names of their own, raising prices in step with a higher profile.

headline.main: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Old Drugs, New Labels; Brand Name Generics and Other Linguistic Anomalies

docs.abstract: Some makers of generic drugs are adopting new business strategies, including devloping brands of their own, to differentiate themselves in sea of cheap knockoffs of brand name drugs; focuses on strategies of Watson Pharmaceuticals, Alpharma Inc and Teva Pharmaceutical Industries; photo of Watson chief executive Allen Chao; chart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The General Assembly concluded a special session on the world drug problem today with the 150 participating nations promising to work to reduce their appetites for illegal drugs within the next five years. The effect was to place reduction of demand on par with reduction of supply as an ''indispensable pillar'' in combating the spread of illegal drugs. Until recently, the drug-fighting strategies of the United States and many other consumer countries focused on intercepting drugs from producing countries.

headline.main: International Effort Is Pledged to Curb Demand for Illegal Drugs

docs.abstract: United Nations General Assembly concludes special session on world drug problem with 150 participating nations promising to work to reduce their appetites for illegal drugs within next five years (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Scientists have broken the code of the tuberculosis bacterium, a germ that kills more people in the world than any other infectious agent. This advance, which is being published today in the journal Nature, is likely to open up new approaches for developing drugs and vaccines against the microbe, and to reinvigorate research efforts in what has been up to now a difficult and slow-moving field.

headline.main: Scientists Decode the DNA Of Germ Responsible for TB

docs.abstract: Scientists have broken code of tuberculosis bacterium, germ that kills more people in world than any other infectious agent; advance, published in June 11 journal Nature, is likely to open up new approaches for developing drugs and vaccines against microbe, and to reinvigorate research efforts in what has been difficult and slow-moving field; it is work of team lead by Dr Stewart T Cole of Pasteur Institute in Paris and Dr Bart G Barrell, DNA sequencer at Sanger Center near Cambridge, England (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Here at the base of the Rocky Mountains, in a region that is the heart of the nation's herbal and vitamin industry, a stainless steel contraption was hard at work on a recent morning, spitting out clear plastic capsules at the rate of 90,000 an hour. Each contained precisely 600 milligrams of a fine, brick-colored powder that Federal health officials are trying to ban. The powder, a pulverized strain of rice fermented with red yeast, is imported from China, where it has been consumed for 2,000 years, as an herbal remedy (it is thought to improve blood flow) and a food (it spices up tofu and makes a tasty marinade for duck and pork.) Then five years ago, William McGlashan Jr., a young California venture capitalist, learned that scientists in Beijing were studying red yeast rice for another reason: it seemed to lower cholesterol.

headline.main: Drug Regulators Make Push To Rein In Herbal Remedies

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration's effort to ban sale of Cholestin as an illegal, unapproved drug is shaping up as pivotal battle between agency and dietary supplement industry, which has grown wildly since 1994 law left agency almost powerless to regulate vitamins and herbal products; FDA claims Cholestin has crossed increasingly murky boundary between dietary supplements and drugs because it contains lovastatin, key component of cholesterol-lowering drug; Pharmanex holds lovastatin occurs naturally in rice; graph of sales of dietary supplements; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Less than one year after it was approved by the Food and Drug Administration, the prescription heart drug Posicor was pulled off pharmacy shelves in 38 countries today, amid mounting evidence that it is dangerous, and possibly lethal, when used in combination with other drugs. The drug, made by Roche Laboratories of Nutley, N.J., is used to treat high blood pressure and the chest pains known as angina, particularly in the elderly. It is used by 400,000 people worldwide, including 200,000 in the United States.

headline.main: Heart Drug Withdrawn as Evidence Shows It Could Be Lethal

docs.abstract: Roche Laboratories withdraws from market at Food and Drug Administration request prescription heart drug Posicor amid mounting evidence that drug is dangerous, and possibly lethal, when used in combination with many other drugs; drug is used to treat high blood pressure and chest pains known as angina, particularly in elderly; FDA and Roche urge patients not to stop taking drug until their doctors prescribe alternative therapy (M)
